docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Harold E. Varmus, the Nobel Prize-winning molecular biologist who has presided over the National Institutes of Health during the greatest expansion in its 112-year history, told President Clinton yesterday that he would resign at the end of the year to become president and chief executive of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. When he left the University of California at San Francisco to go to Washington six years ago, Dr. Varmus had never run anything larger than a research laboratory. His tenure at the National Institutes of Health was blessed by a good economy and an explosion in biomedical research, and he took advantage of both to persuade Congress to increase the agency's budget vastly, to nearly $15.6 billion this year from $10.3 billion in 1993, with a $2 billion increase last year alone.

headline.main: Nobel Winner Is to Head Cancer Center

docs.lead_paragraph: One after another, the lawmakers told anecdotes about constituents who had been harmed when they were denied coverage by their health maintenance organizations. Representative Ron Kind, Democrat of Wisconsin, told of a ''young family in Western Wisconsin'' in which a little girl died after she was denied a treatment for brain cancer.

docs.lead_paragraph: Can you teach an old bull new tricks? Merrill Lynch & Company, the world's largest brokerage firm, is about to find out, as it introduces a set of on-line services intended to transform its buttoned-down brokerage business into a force in electronic commerce. The digital version of Merrill Lynch wants to sell not just stocks and bonds, but steaks and bonbons, too.

headline.main: Merrill Lynch Catches the Spirit; A Traditional Brokerage Firm Spouts the On-Line Gospel

docs.abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co, facing intense competition from on-line brokers, is adopting wide-ranging strategy to attract more assets by offering not just financial services but also E-commerce services to its customers; Merrill has added on-line shopping and auctions to its portfolio of World Wide Web sites in recent weeks; Merrill vice chairman John L Steffens says his company wants to manage 'the total financial relationship' with its customers, not just their investments; contends Merrill account holders will buy about $7 billion in goods and services with their Merrill Visa cards this year; says on-line sales could help raise that total to $100 billion annually within six years; graph; chart; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Michael M. Weinstein (Editorial Observer, Oct. 5) subscribes to the conventional wisdom that President Clinton's 1994 effort failed because of its complexity. He likes Bill Bradley's health care proposal because it ''achieves simplicity by forsaking 100 percent coverage.''
docs.abstract: O'Brien Boldt letter on praise for simplicity of Bill Bradley's health care plan; says Pres Cinton's plan failed because of its huge cost, not because of its well-remembered 1,200 pages; says both plans have same failing: letting health profiteers stay in business

docs.lead_paragraph: Ceres Group Inc., a health insurer, agreed yesterday to buy the Pyramid Life Insurance Company from Unitrin Inc. for $67.5 million to expand sales to people over 65. The companies also agreed that Ceres would sell its medical insurance through agents of Chicago-based Unitrin. Pyramid is Ceres's fourth acquisition since July 1998, giving the company a total of $850 million in assets, a sevenfold increase since the first purchase. Ceres, of Cleveland, sells managed care, health insurance and specialty products and services through 50,000 independent sales agents.

headline.main: UNITRIN TO SELL PYRAMID LIFE TO CERES GROUP

docs.lead_paragraph: The Washington County Fair and its insurer are fighting over whether the fair, which is at the center of the state's worst outbreak of E. coli poisoning, is covered for any potential liability. The fair faces lawsuits seeking at least $100 million after the outbreak sickened hundreds of people who attended the fair and killed two.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Hindu Nationalist Coalition Wins Indian Elections The Bharatiya Janata Party won a clear victory as leader of a centrist coalition of 24 parties that appears to offer India its most durable government in years. The Congress Party, the once dominant political force, suffered a humiliating defeat. A1 Treaty's Fate Tied to U.S. Speakers at a conference convened to press for ratification of the nuclear test-ban treaty -- including two of the major holdouts, Russia and China -- suggested that the ban might founder if it was not ratified by the United States Senate. The Clinton Administration and Senate Republicans agree that the ban faces nearly certain defeat if it comes to a vote, so the major discussion has been about whether, and how, to postpone the vote -- and keep the treaty alive -- at least until next year. A11

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Census Bureau has released the statistics on the number of Americans without health insurance (front page, Oct. 4). From these data it appears that Texas leads the states with almost 25 percent of its population lacking health insurance. Perhaps Texas is really led by a Governor who practices pitiless pragmatism rather than compassionate conservatism. JOHN E. HAMMOND Pittsboro, N.C., Oct. 6, 1999
docs.abstract: John E Hammond letter says Census Bureau data show Texas leads states with almost 25 percent of population lacking health insurance; suggests Gov George W Bush practices not compassionate conservatism but pitiless pragmatism

docs.lead_paragraph: Great-West Lifeco Inc., Canada's largest life insurer, agreed to buy the Allmerica Financial Corporation's group life and health insurance business for undisclosed terms, expanding its presence in the United States. Great-West, based in Winnipeg, Manitoba, will get a business that had $300 million in revenue last year and has 400,000 members. Great-West said it expected to retain a ''significant portion'' of the unit's customers. The transaction follows Great-West's purchase last year of a similar United States business from Anthem Inc. for about $100 million.
